title: Why were there so many civil wars in the Byzantine Empire in the 14th century? With the loss of almost all their territory, what was there to fight over? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think that it's part of the life cycle of nations that in their decline (ineffective bureaucracy, over taxation, economic malaise, poor military morale etc.) are given over to civil wars. The Romans had endured three seasons before just before Diocletian in the 3rd century, Leo III in the 8th, and Alexios I in the 11th. In those times an exceptional emperor emerged, restored order and the empire proceeded to recover. It was both the weakness and the genius of the Roman system. In the 14th century, no such emperor emerged. The closest that Constantinople got to a great emperor in that century would be perhaps Andronikos III, but he was merely a good and competent emperor, not a great one.

Keep in mind that Byzantines didn’t just control their little chunk of land in Anatolia but they had significant territories in the Balkans as well. It was no longer a huge empire but it remained a significant kingdom.
